question: A 32-year-old man had epilepsy. He was treated with carbamazepine 200 mg twice a day. His last serum carbamazepine levels were within normal limits. He was brought to the emergency department after a seizure and his carbamazepine levels were noticed to be low. He had been taking medication regularly, did not use illicit drugs or alcohol and was not on any other medication. What is the most likely explanation?

options.A: Carbamazepine could be absorbed less in the intestine
options.D: Renal excretion of carbamazepine is increased
options.E: There is no reason for his blood levels to be low

options.A: By inducing the enzyme phosphodiesterase V, it raises the levels of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP)
options.B: By inducing the enzyme phosphodiesterase V, it reduces the levels of cGMP
options.C: By inhibiting the enzyme phosphodiesterase V, it raises the levels of cGMP
options.D: By inhibiting the enzyme phosphodiesterase V, it reduces the levels of cGMP
options.E: By inhibiting the enzyme phosphodiesterase V, it has no effect on the levels of cGMP

question: Which of the following explains the mechanism of action of zopiclone?

options.D: Selective binding to the g subunit of GABA-C receptors

question: A 34-year-old woman had depression. She was on fluoxetine 60 mg once a day. Her clinician reduced the dose to 40 mg a day and added mirtazapine 15 mg once a day. Next day, she developed fever, tachycardia, muscle twitches and confusion. Which of the following can explain this reaction?

options.C: MARCKS is implicated in the treatment of epilepsy
options.D: MARCKS is implicated in the treatment of pain
options.E: There is significant down-regulation of MARCKS with repeated use of carbamazepine

options.A: Continue both the drugs without any change
options.B: Continue haloperidol and lithium in reduced dosages
options.C: Stop both the drugs and monitor patient closely
options.E: Stop lithium and switch haloperidol to chlorpromazine

options.C: It should be used at least 12 hours after the last alcohol ingestion
options.D: Its use with alcohol can cause hypotension

options.A: It is measured by the disconcordance rate among twin pairs
options.B: It is a ratio of genetic variance to phenotypic variance
options.C: It is a ratio of phenotypic variance to genetic variance
options.D: It is the proportion of proband twins who have an affected co-twin
options.E: It is the proportion of twin pairs when both of them are affected with the disorder

question: In the example, 'two relatives from same family sharing a common disorder have two alleles in common; one is at LOCI-1 and the other at LOC-2. Co-inheritance of these two alleles along with the disorder in the family tree suggests that some unobserved risk gene for the disorder is present near the loci'. What principle is applied in this case?

options.A: Logarithm of odd score will be 3 or 3+
options.B: Markers will not undergo recombination and will be inherited together
options.C: Markers will not undergo recombination and will not be inherited separately
options.D: Markers will undergo recombination and will be inherited together
options.E: Markers will undergo recombination and will not be inherited separately

question: What is the main difference between association studies and linkage studies?

options.A: For association studies, the DNA marker has to be in the disease gene itself
options.B: For linkage studies, the DNA marker has to be very tightly linked to the disease gene
options.C: Linkage analysis has demonstrated strong links between the human leukocyte antigen system and several diseases
options.D: Mutation analysis of polymorphisms is done by linkage analysis
options.E: Association analysis can be used to 'scan the genome'

options.B: Most genes encode peptides and are transcribed by RNA polymerase 2
options.C: RNA splicing, capping and polyadenylation are pretranscriptional
options.D: Tryptophan is specified by several codons

options.C: Chromosomal variations in chromosome 3 are strongly related to alcoholism

question: What does the term 'envirome' mean?

options.B: The environmental factors that predispose as well trigger psychiatric disorders
options.C: The immediate environment of an individual in which he or she lives
options.D: The internal environment of the individual that leads to a psychiatric disorder

question: Abnormalities of chromosomes can lead to a psychosis that is similar to schizophrenia. Which of the following chromosomes is implicated in psychosis?

options.B: The ecological and social settings that an individual shares with peers
options.C: The ecological environment in which a person lives that modifies the genes
options.D: The internal environment of an individual that modifies the genes
options.E: The social environment in which a person lives that modifies the genes

question: You conducted a family study of patients with recurrent depressive disorder. Your findings showed that there was an increased risk of developing depression in parents' siblings and offsprings as probands, whereas second- and third-degree relatives do not have the increased risk. What does this mean?

options.A: Environmental factors play a more important role in the development of depression than genetic factors
options.B: Genetic factors play a more important role in the development of depression than environment
options.C: There is no role for environmental factors in the development of depression
options.D: There is no role for genetic factors in the development of depression
options.E: This finding does not give any conclusive evidence as to whether genetic or environmental factors play a major role in the development of depression

options.B: Mainly one type of problem behaviour found

question: Which of the following statements about alcohol-related dementia is correct?

options.C: It occurs more in areas of high socioeconomic status

question: Which of the following statements about neurocognition in schizophrenia is correct?

options.C: Deficits in motor skills are more pronounced than in the verbal memory domain

question: Which of the following statements about assessing the personality of an individual is correct?

question: A mother of a 7-year-old boy kept giving him laxatives in his food covertly and frequently took him to the hospital and insisted on his admission. Which of the following statements about this situation is correct?

options.B: Personality disorder is commonly observed among the perpetrators
options.C: The child won't be harmed because he is being cared for in hospital

options.C: One in ten 8-year-old boys has pubic hair
options.D: Puberty lasts longer than in previous generations

question: Who described the 'good-enough mother'?

options.A: Dream content substitutes the target of one's feelings onto another person or object
options.C: It makes sense of the manifest content
options.D: It refers to what we dream about and are aware of on waking

question: Which of the following statements is about neurotic symptoms in psychoanalysis?

options.B: Dreams have different meanings from neurotic symptoms
options.C: The symptoms may symbolise the wish with which they are linked

question: Which of the following describes snags in cognitive–analytical therapy?

options.C: Available action or possible roles limited to polarised alternatives
options.D: Negative assumptions which generate acts that reinforce the assumptions
options.E: Patient helped to recognise recurrences of unrevised patterns

question: In Yalom's universal therapeutic factors, catharsis refers to which of the following?

options.C: Improving one's self-esteem by helping another
options.D: Model helpful behaviours of other members
options.E: Recognition of common experiences and that it reflects experiences in wider society

question: Which of the following statements best describes the technique of paradoxical injunction used in systemic family therapy?

options.A: Different positions are assigned to parts of the family structure
options.B: Members of the family are 'prescribed' their symptom which can paradoxically lead to an alteration
options.C: Practical solutions are developed between family members
options.D: Tasks are assigned to family members to complete between sessions, which involve a change in their actions to see how it affects the system
options.E: Thought is given to how to live with symptoms if they cannot be altered

question: Which of the following is one of the stages of eye-movement desensitisation and reprocessing?

options.D: Step 4 – considered if there is high risk of self-harm
options.E: Step 5 – CBT or drug treatment can be initiated

question: Which of the following statements about psychological treatments for people with an antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) is correct?

options.B: Psychological interventions for almost all of the components of ASPD are well developed

question: Which of the following statements about combined CBT and antidepressants is correct?

options.A: After ending treatment, relapse rates of depression are similar in those treated with either CBT or antidepressants
options.B: CBT is as effective as antidepressant medication in depressed inpatients
options.C: Drug treatments have a higher relapse rate than CBT on discontinuation in generalised anxiety disorder
options.D: The combination of CBT and antidepressant medication may be as effective as either alone in severe depression

question: Which of the following treatments is harmful in post-traumatic stress disorder?

question: A 20-year-old female college student repeatedly self-harmed, expressed feelings of being miserable, lonely and abandoned by family and friends. She found it difficult to maintain romantic relationships. Which of the following is the most appropriate psychological therapy for treatment?

options.B: After long-term deprivation children become self-sufficient through detachment
options.C: Long-term deprivation includes a child going to stay with grandparents, while the mother is on holiday
options.D: Short-term deprivation includes separation after a divorce
options.E: There are no long-term effects of short-term deprivation in children

question: Which of the following is a risk factor related to the parent/environment for child abuse?

question: Which of the following statements about couples and divorce in the UK is correct?

options.B: After divorce, men have a lower rate of remarriage than women
options.C: Couples who cohabit before marriage are unlikely to divorce later
options.D: Divorce rates peak after 10–12 years of marriage
options.E: Divorce rates are highest in individuals in late 30s

question: Which of the following vulnerability factors in parents is considered in identifying children at risk of developing conduct problems?

options.C: At least one parent has a degree of contact with the criminal justice system
options.D: Parents have an education status below the GCSE level

question: Which of the following statements about association between sexual abuse and psychiatric disorder is correct?

options.A: Girls are more prone to psychiatric disorders than boys after sexual abuse
options.B: A history of rape does not add any more to the risks of a psychiatric disorder if sexual abuse had already occurred
options.C: Patients are more prone to psychiatric disorders when they were abused before the age of 10 years compared with after the age of 15 years
options.D: There is enough evidence to show an association between sexual abuse and obsessive–compulsive disorder
options.E: There is a statistically significant association between sexual abuse and lifetime diagnosis of sleep disorders
